abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Sector
            Capacity Building Project for Ethiopia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: this project
            was premised on an overly ambitious objective. The inclusion
            of outcome indicators whose measurement created severe
            problems of attribution in project impact significantly
            complicated the assessment of outcomes. The implementing
            agency had no prior experience in implementing Bank
            projects. A lack of technical expertise and experience with
            regard to procurement procedures led to substantial
            implementation delays. The lesson that can be derived is
            that transition between Task Team Leader's (TTLs) must
            be reduced to a minimum and, where handover is unavoidable
            the Bank should ensure sufficient overlapping time to avoid
            major discontinuities in the dialogue with counterparts and
            in the overall consistency of Bank interventions.
            Appropriate restructuring actions should be considered when
            major parts of a project are cancelled. Payment systems and
            credit information systems are technically complex and
            require adequate time to implement.
